nexttext:
Therefore the derivative of this equation becomes Eq.$(\ref{engyc})$ in this case, too.\par
   Since $ T^{\mu}_{\hspace{5pt}a} $ is the energy momentum tensor of the matter , it is natural to consider $ t^{\mu}_{\hspace{5pt}a} $ as the GEMT. Then Eq.$(\ref{engyc})$ means a conservation law of total energy momentum tensor. This equation is covariant under the general coordinate transformation because the energy momentum tensor has only one world coordinate index. Since the energy momentum tensors are written with two world coordinate indices usually, the energy conservation law does not transform covariantly. The general relativity has the other invariance of a global Lorenz transformation, too. But, this symmetry does not break  Eq.$(\ref{engyc})$.\par
 We can derive the GEMT with Eqs.$(\ref{4.2}),(\ref{VVV})$ and the equation of motion . It is acquired as

\begin{eqnarray}
et^\mu_{\hspace{5pt}a}&=& \frac{1}{16\pi}(e^\mu_a e R-2eR^\mu_{\hspace{5pt}a} +\partial_\lambda e(c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu}-c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}a}+c^{\mu\lambda}_{\hspace{10pt}a}))\\
 & =&\frac{e}{16\pi}(e^\mu_a R-2R^\mu_a+\nabla_\lambda c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu}+\nabla_\lambda c^{\mu\lambda}_{\hspace{10pt} a}+\frac{1}{2}c_{a\lambda\sigma}c^{\mu\lambda\sigma}+c_{\lambda\sigma a}c^{\lambda\sigma\mu}+c_{\lambda\sigma a}c^{\sigma\lambda\mu} \nonumber \\
& & { }\qquad -\nabla_\lambda c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt} a}). \label{GEMT1}
\end{eqnarray}

The last term of an above equation is antisymmetric. We will show that it is zero by the conservation law of a spin angular momentum tensor. In the case of the other decomposition  Eq.$(\ref{GR})$, we obtain the same result, too. It is well known that the Eq.$(\ref{TEGR})$ and Eq.$(\ref{2.1})$ are equivalent. This result ensures the equivalence furthermore.\par
 The following identities are useful in a derivation.

\begin{eqnarray}
R^\mu_{\hspace{5pt}a}&=&\frac{1}{2}\nabla_\lambda(c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt} a}-c^{\mu \lambda}_{\hspace{10pt}a}-c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu})+\nabla_a c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}\lambda}-\frac{1}{2}c^{\sigma}_{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\sigma}(c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}a}-c^{\mu\lambda}_{\hspace{10pt}a}-c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu})\nonumber \\ 
&&{}+\frac{1}{2}c^{\mu\sigma\lambda}c_{\sigma\lambda a}- \frac{1}{4}c^{\mu\sigma\lambda}c_{a\sigma\lambda}\\
&=& \frac{1}{2}\nabla_\lambda(c^{\mu\lambda}_{\hspace{10pt}a}+ c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu})
 +\frac{1}{2}(\nabla_a c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}\lambda}+\nabla^\mu c^\lambda_{\hspace{5pt}a\lambda}) 
  +\frac{1}{2}(c^{\mu\nu}_{\hspace{10pt}a} +c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\nu\mu}) c^\lambda_{\hspace{5pt}\nu\lambda}.
\end{eqnarray}

Therefore the derivative of this equation becomes Eq.$(\ref{engyc})$ in this case, too.\par
   Since $ T^{\mu}_{\hspace{5pt}a} $ is the energy momentum tensor of the matter , it is natural to consider $ t^{\mu}_{\hspace{5pt}a} $ as the GEMT. Then Eq.$(\ref{engyc})$ means a conservation law of total energy momentum tensor. This equation is covariant under the general coordinate transformation because the energy momentum tensor has only one world coordinate index. Since the energy momentum tensors are written with two world coordinate indices usually, the energy conservation law does not transform covariantly. The general relativity has the other invariance of a global Lorenz transformation, too. But, this symmetry does not break  Eq.$(\ref{engyc})$.\par
 We can derive the GEMT with Eqs.$(\ref{4.2}),(\ref{VVV})$ and the equation of motion . It is acquired as

\begin{eqnarray}
et^\mu_{\hspace{5pt}a}&=& \frac{1}{16\pi}(e^\mu_a e R-2eR^\mu_{\hspace{5pt}a} +\partial_\lambda e(c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu}-c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}a}+c^{\mu\lambda}_{\hspace{10pt}a}))\\
 & =&\frac{e}{16\pi}(e^\mu_a R-2R^\mu_a+\nabla_\lambda c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu}+\nabla_\lambda c^{\mu\lambda}_{\hspace{10pt} a}+\frac{1}{2}c_{a\lambda\sigma}c^{\mu\lambda\sigma}+c_{\lambda\sigma a}c^{\lambda\sigma\mu}+c_{\lambda\sigma a}c^{\sigma\lambda\mu} \nonumber \\
& & { }\qquad -\nabla_\lambda c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt} a}). \label{GEMT1}
\end{eqnarray}

The last term of an above equation is antisymmetric. We will show that it is zero by the conservation law of a spin angular momentum tensor. In the case of the other decomposition  Eq.$(\ref{GR})$, we obtain the same result, too. It is well known that the Eq.$(\ref{TEGR})$ and Eq.$(\ref{2.1})$ are equivalent. This result ensures the equivalence furthermore.\par
 The following identities are useful in a derivation.

\begin{eqnarray}
R^\mu_{\hspace{5pt}a}&=&\frac{1}{2}\nabla_\lambda(c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt} a}-c^{\mu \lambda}_{\hspace{10pt}a}-c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu})+\nabla_a c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}\lambda}-\frac{1}{2}c^{\sigma}_{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\sigma}(c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}a}-c^{\mu\lambda}_{\hspace{10pt}a}-c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu})\nonumber \\ 
&&{}+\frac{1}{2}c^{\mu\sigma\lambda}c_{\sigma\lambda a}- \frac{1}{4}c^{\mu\sigma\lambda}c_{a\sigma\lambda}\\
&=& \frac{1}{2}\nabla_\lambda(c^{\mu\lambda}_{\hspace{10pt}a}+ c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\lambda\mu})
 +\frac{1}{2}(\nabla_a c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}\lambda}+\nabla^\mu c^\lambda_{\hspace{5pt}a\lambda}) 
  +\frac{1}{2}(c^{\mu\nu}_{\hspace{10pt}a} +c_a^{\hspace{5pt}\nu\mu}) c^\lambda_{\hspace{5pt}\nu\lambda}.
\end{eqnarray}

nexttext:
where $\gamma$ is determinant of 3-D space time metric and $K$ is a trace of an  extrinsic curvature. $K_0$ is the  trace of the  extrinsic curvature which is made of flat space time metric. It is called subtraction term. $\epsilon$ is +1 when a boundary is time-like and is -1 when the boundary is space-like. \par
 The integration of $ K $ is expressed with tetrad as

\begin{eqnarray}
 \frac{2\epsilon}{16\pi}\int d^3 x \sqrt {\gamma} K&=& 
-\frac{1}{8\pi}\int d^3 x \sqrt{\gamma}N c^{\lambda\zeta}_{\hspace{10pt}\lambda} \nonumber\\
&=&-\frac{1}{8\pi}\int d^3 x \sqrt{\gamma}\,n_\mu c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}\lambda},
\end{eqnarray}

where $ n_\mu $ is an  orthonormal vector of the boundary and $N$ is a lapse function.We assume the boundary is $\zeta=const.$ hypersurface. In this expression, it is not necessary to introduce $\epsilon$.
In order to make the GEMT from GH term we should treat GH term as a volume term of 3-D boundary not a surface term of 4-D space-time.\par
The effect of GH term  to GEMT is given by

where $\gamma$ is determinant of 3-D space time metric and $K$ is a trace of an  extrinsic curvature. $K_0$ is the  trace of the  extrinsic curvature which is made of flat space time metric. It is called subtraction term. $\epsilon$ is +1 when a boundary is time-like and is -1 when the boundary is space-like. \par
 The integration of $ K $ is expressed with tetrad as

\begin{eqnarray}
 \frac{2\epsilon}{16\pi}\int d^3 x \sqrt {\gamma} K&=& 
-\frac{1}{8\pi}\int d^3 x \sqrt{\gamma}N c^{\lambda\zeta}_{\hspace{10pt}\lambda} \nonumber\\
&=&-\frac{1}{8\pi}\int d^3 x \sqrt{\gamma}\,n_\mu c^{\lambda\mu}_{\hspace{10pt}\lambda},
\end{eqnarray}

where $ n_\mu $ is an  orthonormal vector of the boundary and $N$ is a lapse function.We assume the boundary is $\zeta=const.$ hypersurface. In this expression, it is not necessary to introduce $\epsilon$.
In order to make the GEMT from GH term we should treat GH term as a volume term of 3-D boundary not a surface term of 4-D space-time.\par

nexttext:
Here, $i,j$ and $ k$ are 3-D world coordinates and $\alpha$ and $\beta$  are 3-D local Lorenz coordinates in the boundary. In these equations $\zeta's $  are not summed.  The $\bar{e}^\nu_a$ and $\bar{c}_{\mu\nu\lambda}$ are flat space time quantities corresponding to $ e^\nu_a$ and $c_{\mu\nu\lambda}$. The derivatives of $ \bar{e}^b_{\lambda,\sigma}$ by $e^\beta_{j,i}$ are
usually vanish because $\bar{e}$ is flat space time quantity. However,for an example, $\bar{e}^2_\theta$ and $\bar{e}^3_\phi$ are same with the corresponding tetrads of Schwarzschild black hole. In that case the derivative of $\bar{e}^2_{\theta,\sigma}$ by  $e^2_{\theta, i}$ does not vanish. Therefore in Eq.($\ref{GH2}$), we can not describe a concrete formula of the general case.


 
\section{GRAVITATIONAL ENERGY}
In this section, we consider the GEMT in three examples, gravitational wave, Schwarzschild black hole and FLRW universe.\par
As a first example, we consider the GEMT of the gravitational wave. The gravitational wave is usually considered as a weak plane wave in the flat space time. There are two modes in the gravitational wave, but we consider only one mode moving to z-direction for simplicity. We take a transverse trace-less gauge. Therefor we can assume a metric as $g_{\mu\nu}=diag(-1,1+h_{xx},1+h_{yy},1)$. $ h_{xx}=Acos(kt-kz)=-h_{yy}$. Since a space time has no boundary, we need not the effect of GH term in the GEMT. The gravitational wave is not an exact solution of Einstein equation, but is a weak field approximation. So the Einstein tensor in the GEMT is written with $h_{xx}$ and $ h_{yy}$ as an approximation in order two. The $(t,t)$ component of GEMT is given by

\section{GRAVITATIONAL ENERGY}
In this section, we consider the GEMT in three examples, gravitational wave, Schwarzschild black hole and FLRW universe.\par
As a first example, we consider the GEMT of the gravitational wave. The gravitational wave is usually considered as a weak plane wave in the flat space time. There are two modes in the gravitational wave, but we consider only one mode moving to z-direction for simplicity. We take a transverse trace-less gauge. Therefor we can assume a metric as $g_{\mu\nu}=diag(-1,1+h_{xx},1+h_{yy},1)$. $ h_{xx}=Acos(kt-kz)=-h_{yy}$. Since a space time has no boundary, we need not the effect of GH term in the GEMT. The gravitational wave is not an exact solution of Einstein equation, but is a weak field approximation. So the Einstein tensor in the GEMT is written with $h_{xx}$ and $ h_{yy}$ as an approximation in order two. The $(t,t)$ component of GEMT is given by

It is easy to understand that $ t_{tt}(GH)=0$ at $r=2M $ with Eq.($\ref{Eout}$).
It is not necessary to include the subtraction term when the boundary exists at
finite distance. Therefore, there is not any contribution to the energy from the horizon.\par
After all, in the Schwarzschild black hole the gravitational energy exists only in the outer region of the horizon. There is no gravitational energy in the black hole.
